description: Honestly have to say ever since I moved to San Francisco, I've become a coffee person. This was my first time visiting the Beanery and I really enjoyed the scenery. This location was located in a cozy little spot around a intersection. It was a plus to enjoy a cup of joe while enjoying the San Francisco lifestyle. One odd thing I didn't like was that they have a $4 limit per transaction and in this given day. I don't really carry cash anymore. I had to add another item to meet the limit. Overall, I would definitely stop by again and bring cash.
author: AJ P.

description:
Not really my cup of coffee, but a-ok.

Really nice decor, and it looks like they roast their own coffee on occasion (huge roaster and permit to use it in the front).

Ambiance is attractive, and if I wanted to hang out (assuming there was an open space), this might be nice.

From a drinks perspective, I'll admit that I'm not that knowledgeable about the ins and outs, hows and wheres.  But I know what I like, and the mocha has a slight burnt water taste that I am always wary of in my coffee.

Will I be back? Probably not.  But I'll look inside and smile.
author: Anna D.

description: We were visiting SF and a friend of ours made us a cup of the house blend. We loved it so much we bought ourselves some to take home to San Diego!
author: Kaitlyn N.

description:
Pretty small interior. Nice staff. Nothing too special! It is so small that when the door opens the place gets really cold.

Had an iced coffee - solid!
author: Emily H.

description: I've lived in the neighborhood for one year and I go to this location every Saturday and most Sundays, too. I usually order a latte and a pastry, and have never really been disappointed (I love the coffee, the pastries are just ok). However, I think only one employee here is somewhat friendly. The woman with dark hair who is often making the coffee on Saturday mornings is awful and has never even looked at me. Even after coming here every weekend for a year and spending on average $15 a week (on coffee and a pastry) the negativity from the staff is making me want to find a new place - or walk a little farther to the other Beanery location. I worked in customer service for a long time so I know it can be stressful and hard work. But even on my worst days I still always greeted customers with a friendly smile. This one woman in particular should find a new career if she can't force a smile occasionally.
author: Kate A.

description: Great fresh tasting French Roast (sign says organic).  Great service-the gal running the tiny coffee spot was friendly!  $2.00 even for an excellent cuppa house blend!  Thank you for a great experience!
author: Molly M.

description: I can't vouch for anything aside from the soy chai latte and lemon poppyseed cookie because it's just that good. Very small establishment (smaller than the one down the street), but I prefer it cozy like this.
author: Anna Z.

description: Terrible service, sucks to start your Sunday morning getting attitude with your coffee.
author: Robert S.

description:
Excellent fresh coffee, Great service. Cute shop, not too many seats and tables. 

Will definitely visit again.
author: Z ..

description: 3rd time I've been here where the self serve half n half is spoiled.  The employees are also the least friendly of the many other great neighborhood coffee shops.  Really wanted to like it since it's so close, so I kept giving it more chances.  I guess I just have to throw in the towel on this place.  I would recommend literally any other nearby coffee shop to this one.
author: Meredith S.

description: Nonfat triple latte $4.60. Pretty average. No better than Peet's. Watery, pretty monotone. Just happy to find a place that serves nonfat milk in SF though.
author: Will N.

description: I try to support our local cafes but I unfortunately don't think I'll stop by here again. I came in for a hot chocolate and bagel with sundried tomato to go. Unfortunately I left with the wrong type of bagel and plain cream cheese. By the time I realized it, I was already too far to go back. At least I left with a hot chocolate? Well, that would have been more comforting if the hot chocolate tasted okay. :/
author: Sari S.

description: Good vibe. Being a Starbucks girl I didn't know really what to order. So I got an ice coffee and asked for vanilla to be put in for me with some room for cream. I didn't get my vanilla.  So I had to use splenda to sweeten it which isn't that good. The tables were really unique. They table tops had coffee beans under the glass top. Pretty cool.
author: Sarah Y.

description:
Ethiopian!
I was with a Nicaraguan guy having a coffee break here.
He was telling me about how bad the Sandinistas, made a deal with Chinese to built canal, but did not work because local Nicaraguan Indians don't want to deal with them.
He also told me that coffee that Nicaraguan has is very very strong. He almost having a heart attack after drinking the coffee.
Btw, I forgot to ask him about is there any Chinatown in Nicaragua.

A quiet and small spot for some good caffeine. They also have a good variety of pastries and biscotti.
I like to support local small business like this!
author: Nobu K.

description:
Came here for a quick business meeting with a colleague.  

The staff is very friendly and helpful.  And the size of this location is very cozy, compared to the 9th Ave. location.  Seating is more conversation oriented than for working, although there is free wifi.

The reason for my 3 star rating is the coffee.  I consider myself a coffee tasting hobbyist and wasn't at all satisfied with the Roasters Blend drip coffee.  

You'll experience a roasted and burnt flavor profile that lines up better with a french roast.  But here, it went one step beyond a french roast with an overpowering taste that's best described as ashy and acrid, slightly skunky.  It had a very heavy body and coating.  The ending left a dirty aftertaste.  And there was a notable amount sludge that I would only expect from French Press style brewing.

Some people prefer this type of taste.  I am not one of them.  The closest I can compare it to is to the packaged and pre-ground French Roast Classic coffee from Peerless Coffee.

I feel terrible writing this review because I absolutely want to support local roasters.  But there's a problem here between the over-roasting and the under-brewing that left me disappointed.

However, I'll be back to try a different roast next time.  Look for an updated review soon!
author: Bobby L.

description:
The Beanery definitely has their regulars and then the random visitors...me being part of the second group. The baristas were friendly enough, but I was literally table jacked by a guy who walked in after me. He threw his newspaper down on the table I sat at like he owned the place and then sat down. My friend and I kind of just looked at each other dumbfoundedly before migrating to one of their other 4 tables. 

I ordered an Americano...and it was just alright. Given that Americanos are either prepared with espresso poured into hot water (or vice versa), I did expect the flavor to be tempered a bit...but overall it was just watery. Hmm.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Located right on the corner of 7th Ave and Irving St, the storefront is facing Irving St with a couple of small tables outside. Forewarning, this area is notorious for difficulty in finding parking. We walked by because we desperately needed caffeine and wanted some place to hang out while we waited for our table at San Tung. A fairly small coffee shop with dim lighting inside, there's a beautiful coffee roasting machine proudly displayed called the San Franciscan. With only about 5 tables inside (with very cool tabletops that have beans glued underneath a pane of glass), not the best place for a group of people to hang out over a warm drink. One unisex bathroom available.

If you're interested in tea, they use Stash Teas. Next to the register is a glass display where a selection of pastries are also available. Their coffee is all fair trade as well.

Menu
Drinks: Single / Double / Triple / Iced - 20oz
Espresso: $1.75 / $2.25 / $2.75 / $2.50
Macchiato: $1.95 / $2.45 / $2.95
Americano: $1.95 / $2.45 / $2.95 / $2.50
Cappuccino: $2.75 / $3.25 / $3.75 / $3.50
Latte: $2.85 / $3.35 / $3.85 / $3.50
Caramel Latte: $3.15 / $3.65 / $4.15 / $3.65
Mocha: $3.10 / $3.60 / $4.10 / $3.65
White Mocha: $3.15 / $3.65 / $4.15 / $3.75
Depth Charge: $2.70 / $3.20 / $3.70 / $3.25

Drinks: Small / Medium / Large / Iced - 20oz
House Coffee $1.75 / $2 / $2.25 / $2.10
Coffee Refill: $0.75 / $0.95 / $1 / $1
Cafe au Lait: $2.35 / $2.60 / $2.85
Chai: $2.85 / $3.35 / $3.85 / $3.50
Tea: N/A / $1.85 / $1.95 / $1.95
Hot Chocolate: $2.25 /$ 2.50 / $2.75
Milk: $2 /$ 2.25 / $2.50
Italian Soda: $2.25
Hot Water: $1
Soy Milk / Flavor / Upsize: $0.35

They have something called a Depth Charge which was explained to me as a shot of espresso in house coffee. Other cafes call the same drink as a red eye, the turbo, the sludge cup, or a shot in the dark.

I ordered a Single Mocha. It was very frothy at the top and had enough sweetness and cocoa flavor where I didn't need to add any type of sweetener. My friend ordered a double cappuccino and his cup's froth looked like fresh snow. It was very amusing. The caffeine didn't seem very strong, but we both still enjoyed our cup.

Service was decent. Answered my question. Not rude but not really friendly either.

Wouldn't go out of my way to come here but wouldn't mind stopping by if I'm in the area and needed a caffeine fix.
author: Kitty K.

description:
Tried the latte here and was disappointed. Maybe I expected too much after reading the great reviews about The Beanery, but I thought it was weak and lacked any depth of flavor. Didn't taste much different from what I make at home, which is basically brewed coffee with some milk added - it's not even espresso! Basically, I didn't feel it was worth my money.

Service was chilly. Maybe because I'm only a college student? Or Asian? Maybe they were just having a bad day. Nevertheless, I didn't feel very welcome here.

There were a few small tables inside and outside. I liked the tables - sheets of glass with beans under them - but I don't think I'd want to sit there for very long. At most, grab n' go.
author: Ivonnie S.

description: Cute little shop, barista was really friendly. Had a lot of outlets and good wifi. I ordered an iced chai latte, couldn't taste any chai, taste like burnt milk. My boyfriend got a hot chai which tasted a little better so maybe that's the way to go.
author: Rachael R.

description:
Great coffee, have not tried anything else. so TBA :)

Nice place!
author: Albia C.

description:
I set out late that morning having squared off against the dense fog that threatened to keep me indoors. Marching deliberately down the hill, I came at first slowly upon the other adventurers. I like to imagine that our shared smiles indicate a kind of acknowledgement: "it is we who brave this wilderness." 

The inner sunset has a lovely crunching quality to the cement, which is peppered with sand from the underlying slope and soil from the small, square plots set aside for a line of trees. I arrived at a clearing in the fog set, as if by magic, at the corner of 7th and Irving where my usual haunt was winding down for the morning. The rush of people headed to work had thinned, leaving a single seat by the window ready for my intended task. I was writing a letter, you see. 

"Rachel, I will have a small chai please" (I was feeling exotic). Rachel was busy leading the newest employees in a whirl of activity and steamed milk. She always manages to be both busy and accommodating--a nice quality in a coffee shop if you ask me. Bustling but comfortable. Perfect for my letter.

I sat down: "My dearest Emmalee, today my adventure began with a hazy wandering and a spiced chai. How ever shall I top it in the coming hours?"
author: Virginia S.

description: Grabbed a cup of drip coffee and a veggie bagel breakfast sandwich. Solid coffee, great sandwich, and very kind and good service. Nothing flashy, but perfect for what it is. I would totally return and will when in the area.
author: Matthew W.

description: Adorable little coffee shop with amazing coffee and fresh pastries.  This place is little and quiet if you're lucky enough to score one of the few inside tables. They are tables outside for sidewalk searing which is nice for people watching.
author: Lynsey S.

description:
Simple review: The espresso drinks in this place are delicious. If you want a delicious drink, then come to this place. 

Other notes: the staff are cool, the place is cozy.
author: James P.

description:
Cute little coffee stop. Being immediately immersed in the fine aromas here when you walk in is a great feeling. Chairs and tables all alongside the wall in here will be seating happy and satisfied customers. Many are just enjoying that day and reading newspapers, others are catching up, others are studying, but whatever you are doing in a coffee shop, the Beanery is the perfect place to do it. Hot chocolate and coffee come out in large mugs and they have a fun assortment of bakery goods to offer. Being on the corner of 9th street is great for people watching, too! 
It's one of those places that leave an impression.
author: Tuwie N.

description:
Beanery is a good ol friendly neighborhood joint for a coffee. The coffee and staff are pretty good! I'm a fan of the soy mocha latte ($3.45 for a small single shot) or the iced drinks ~$4. The price is about right for coffee - on par with chains like Starbucks and Peet's. 

The great vibe from the staff and decent coffee can't take away from the small space of Beanery. It's not the best place to bring a book and read because there really isn't much space at all. You get a lot of hustle and bustle of people running in and out. So if you're looking for a coffee house to work in, this isn't your best choice. Also - they don't take card, which can be kind of tough in our plastic world.
author: Christine B.

description:
I've been here before Yelp was created and revisited last week since a local storefront was closed.  The taste was exactly the same as I had remembered it before my coffee-tized palate could recognize a good roast.  Ordered a cappuccino - coffee was burnt and they just put a spoonful of frothed milk on top.  

Would not return though they have some committed regulars.  Only upside is very efficient service.
author: Kevin H.

description: Iced caramel latte was top notch and service was quick and friendly! Will definitely be back for more
author: Emma B.

description:
The west is the best, when it comes to coffee, right? We have Starbucks, Peets, Coffee People, Blue Bottle, Stumptown, Philz, Equator, and more every month.

Not too many places stay small and local, though, roasting in small batches and concerned with keeping quality high and prices low. Must be tempting to expand, make more money and get everyone talking about how great you are, even though you are no longer as good as your reputation would warrant.

That's why I love, love, love the Beanery, and this location best of all.

If you thought dark roast had to be bitter, try the French Roast here. It's not burned or astringent at all, just really, really rich and smooth and full of about a million subtle flavors. You can enjoy a good cup of hot deliciousness here or take home a pound and drink it all morning, like I do. Thank me now or thank me later. You're welcome.

And you know how some places fake that friendly environment? Asking your name only to get your order out faster, and engaging in idiotic small talk like they really, really like you. But when you come back and get a refill, they start all over - same idiotic small talk, same conversation. You weren't special.

Here, it's different. I'll go every week for a while, and then go out of town for months. When I return, Heather remembers not only my name, but my preferred, picky blend, and what grind I get. I'm not talkative, but she's so pleasant and calm that she makes me feel comfortable. Nothing fake about her, the coffee, any of it.

To me, this location has the best vibe (less tourists, more UCSF interns studying, quiet yet not too full or too empty). This is what a coffee shop should be, and is.

Nothing fake about it.
author: Charlie B.

description: Stopped in for an afternoon coffee and some writing time while I was in SF. This place fills the bill;  great coffee, good baristas, a decent selection of treats to go along with your cup, and friendly service. Oh yeah and its near Golden Gate park too. What's not to love?
author: David Z.

description: Love that they have fair trade coffee and tea(Numi)! Lots of pretty good looking pastries shipped in from Semifreddi's. Black coffee is $1.65-2.15 and is self serve. There are 5 2-person tables inside and 4 2-person tables outside. Very quiet atmosphere with gentle music. Perfect for studying. 1 star off for the unfriendly and somewhat rude cashier lady, but after she left, a different, much more cheerful lady took her place. Wifi password: 602irving
author: Alice R.

description:
What the...

Ordered two lattes. Paid for two lattes.  Got home, I had one latte and a tea??.  "The Beanery, losing customers due to incompetence everyday!"
author: Alex S.

description: Absolutely the best chai tea with almond milk I ever had :) The lemon poppyseed was delicious too!!!
author: Erika Y.

description:
Best coffee in San Francisco, sorry Blue Bottle. Or actually, I'm not sorry but you should be. Blue Bottle isn't shy about charging outrageous prices for pretty good beans. The Beanery, on the other hand, stopped selling their magnificent Kenyan beans when the price became too steep. 

Since their Kenyan beans are the best coffee I've ever tasted, and I have tasted more than most people, being a previous coffee buyer, I would have paid whatever they'd asked. But you gotta love a business with values as good as their beans.

Heather, one of the managers, mentioned to me that they might be getting the Kenyan back, at least for a short time. She asked me if I'd like to be notified. I gave her my card but - hey - who does that? I didn't think about it again.

Until she actually called. Again, who does that?

I bought about five pounds and shared it with every coffee drinker I knew, and every one of them said it was unbelievable. They told me this weeks later - that's how long they remembered how good it was. They still talk about it and complain that nothing they can buy locally compares to it. No kidding.

This location is just a block closer to UC, smaller, and with a quiet, studious ambience. There are less tourists and less sun on hot days (when we get hot days - and you can distinguish the locals because we are the squinting and sneezing ones).

Good, real, thoughtful, interesting people work here. Please treat them with respect. They make my world a better place.
author: Jill B.

description:
Love this place. The coffee beans are the real deal. Every once in awhile I like some pansy ass coffee from Ritual/Four Barrel but if you want a REAL cup of coffee, get their Mocha Java beans. There is a chocolate flavor in there that just gives it an extra richness. We also just got the organic Guatemalan beans and they are also fantastic.
Joe is the nicest guy and Rachel is a killer barista. These guys make the best cappuccinos I have ever had. Creamy delicious foam piled high. Love you guys!
author: Celeste R.

description:
My Ratings:
Quantity: 4 - Good
Quality: 4 - Tasty!
Price: 4 - Good.
Location: 2 - Small with a few chairs and tables
Parking: 3 - Street parking
Service: 4 - Friendly
Speed: 4 - Quick

Overall: Tasty coffee and wonderful service!

My Opinion/Story:
I was visiting my friend who took me here. I was feeling sluggish and their Iced Coffee perked me up.  I like the cuteness of the place and the casual vibe of it.  My friend and I could have sat inside forever if it weren't for our metered parking.  Service is awesome and quick.
author: Cherryl D.

description:
Cute coffee shop! Their drinks are pretty good and they roast the beans themselves! My husband wasn't a fan of their straight espresso, but we both enjoy the espresso-based drinks.

The baristas are always super nice and the softly playing music is awesome. Seating is limited, but it is a sleepy little place, so I usually manage to find a spot. Free wi-fi, but no outlets. $5 minimum on credit card purchases.
author: Felicia C.

description:
That tall guy is really friendly, prompt, and makes a design in my latte :D
Great service & coffee
author: Miss J.

description: I love the Beanery! They have two locations within 2 blocks, and I wish there were more in San Francisco. The people who work there (at both locations) are very nice. They know my order since I go pretty often. Although it is hard to get a place to sit sometimes, I still stop to get a coffee every once in a while especially when I have time in the morning. Love it!!! Don't go to Starbucks in the area, and support this local business!
author: Diego L.

description: This is a high-quality place to grab a cup of coffee. House coffee/no room for cream: great, smooth, medium-heavy, no bitter...  (other visit) regular latte: perfect pull, good consistency, adequate foam atop. I like the brand name (BEANERY). Actually, anything with the word BEAN in it's brand name would elicit a grin from me.
author: Derek N.

description:
I like coffee. No, scratch that-I love coffee. That being said, I must have a hell of a tolerance for caffeine 'cause the Depth Shot I got here did absolutely nothing for me. I like the combination of coffee and espresso because it gets the job done but the mocha blend coffee with the shot didn't help me perk up. I was kind of disappointed to say the least but that's not why I'm giving this place 3 stars. 

I noticed our barista was smoking outside before coming in to take my order and make my coffee, which is not an issue with me. The fact that I didn't see her wash her hands or even hear the water getting turned on made me a little wary of the sanitation practices overall. I did also notice that there was a fly in their bakery case and that immediately turned me off their sweets. 

On the plus side though, there's no line (I wonder why?) and there's usually a couple parking spots in the usually busy neighborhood. I'm now at a toss up between this place and Starbucks. Regardless of the skeevy feeling, I still want to give this place another chance 'cause it's a smaller place with a more local feel.
author: Jessica K.
Deborah C.

description: I like how they have fair trade coffee so I stopped by to try a decaf latte. It was pretty good. Tastes very similar to Philz coffee. Good coffee.
author: Carmen L.

description: Really great sense of community here. There are a lot of regulars, many of whom the barista knows by name. They have organic and non-organic fresh roasted beans, Semifreddi's fresh baked goods and a selection of teas. The only downsides I can think of is that it closes at 6pm (but is open at 6am, 7am on Sundays), and only has to-go cups; otherwise, 5 stars from me.
author: I Like T.

description:
So I needed a good coffee shop early on a Sunday morning to study. I walked by the Beanery on 9th, but it seemed too crowded, so I ended up here. 

I just had a latte and thought it may have been too milky (next time I might get a double). It wasn't bad, but it wasn't great. This review is not for the coffee or food but for the ambiance and service.

Service
Really great! Friendly and fast!

Ambiance
Also really great. It was a bit small but it seemed that everyone knew each other. However it was also surprisingly conducive to studying! 

Overall I would definitely come here again.  It's awesome
author: Sonia J.

description: Had the strongest cappuccino of my life here. If you need a powerful pick-me-up in the mornings, head to the Beanery.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
I found that anything organic tastes worse and of course, costs more... have you noticed that too? 

Organic chicken: dry
Organic vegetables: tiny
Organic soup: bland 

MEH, gimme chemicals!!

But the organic French Roast here was great - smooth and full bodied. It's no Philz, but I'm not complaining when I can have my Good Earth froyo from next door, my pizza from Arizmendi, AND my coffee.
author: Jess C.

description: Nice music on the background, very chilled, not crowded and best Chai in the city!
author: Duygu G.

description:
This review is 12 year too late. I used to live in the neighborhood and hit the beanery at least once a day. I moved to NOPA 6 months ago and NOPA has some amazing coffee places but nothing comes close to the beanery 

It's quintessential neighborhood cafe where everyone knows your name and you get to meet your neighbors. The coffee is excellent. i still come few times a month to stock up on beans. Try their Guatemala Antigua it's probably the bets coffee out there an yes I have tried Blue bottle, sightglass, philz etc.
author: Subhash J.

description:
I live and work near this place so I go almost daily. The Roaster's Blend is good and the staff are excellent. 

In particular, I want to thank Martin, one of the workers here, who helped me recover an important notebook with my entire life's schedule in it that I lost on MUNI. I had come into the shop right after getting off the N Judah and immediately realized I had left it on the train. When I freaked out, Martin volunteered to take his motorcycle and chase after the train to look for it. I really didn't think he would be able to find it, but I thought it was sweet of him to make the effort. In fact, he actually did find it and return it to me. Martin is my hero! He deserves a raise for going above and beyond the call of duty.... I think he was getting off his shift at the time so he was off work and did me a major favor which was kind and generous...
author: Shelley D.

description: Cute little corner coffee shop.  Love their soy mocha.  Got Starbucks beat by a long shot.  Their pastries are good too, especially the apricot and pecan bars.  Glad I work near here now so I can stop by often.
author: Irene T.

description: The cappuccino to go is surprisingly pretty good. It's not famous third-wave brand coffee but..it's pretty tasty.
author: Jordan G.

description: The Beanery is a very tiny coffee house but they have some of the best coffee that I have had in SF.  It's got great ambiance and the staff is very friendly.  Even when flooded with customers they do a great job in handling everyone with a smile on their face.  I'm also pleased with the size of the iced coffee - really feel that I am getting my money's worth!
author: Sonya T.

description:
I had to be at work in an hour and I was feeling slightly tipsy from the three glasses of Chardonnay I had with my sushi.  I thought it would be wise to get some caffeine in my bloodstream to counteract the alcohol levels I have in there. 

So convenient to have this coffe shop a block away from Ten Sushi.  I got the Roasted Blend drip to go, along with a chocolate croissant (I needed dessert, since we had to leave in the middle of the white elephant gift exchange so I can be at work on time!!!) 

The coffee hit the spot.  It was light bodied and only needed a splash of half and half to give it creaminess. The croissant could've used a little more butter though. (since my sushi lunch was waaaaay too healthful tasting) 

Oops. I guess I better get back to work. (and the rest of my coffee)
author: Janice C.

description:
went in, got coffee, realized that i have no change - the guy at the counter says, "no problem - just pay me later." i replied, "I'll come back tomorrow," to which the guy responds, "sure."

I was so impressed by his response that i went back to the atm, got some cash, out and returned in 1 hour to pay for my coffee. 

what a friendly coffee shop! feels pretty personal - can't get this experience at a chain. and not to mention the good quality coffee, which i enjoyed =D
author: SSS K.

description:
The first consideration when going to the Beanery is: which Beanery?  The one at 9th and Irving has twice the reviews (and twice the decoration budget, apparently), plus proximity to Arizmendi.  But the one at 7th and Irving has Megan W and Random J's approval, a lot less crowds, plus proximity to my house.  So it really depends on whether I want baked goods (I should point out that they have good scones and muffins here, but not good enough to forego the 2-block walk to AB).

How's the coffee?  I won't lie, I'd still like to see Inner Sunset get a place of Cafe Bello caliber, but barring that, Beanery's brew is as good as you could ask for.  And you can even add blackberry syrup.
author: Wes M.

description: The coffee here is pretty good, but the main I am giving this specific location 4 stars is because of the service. Every time I have gone in here, the people that ring me up have a smile on their face and are very friendly.  I also like how cozy the ambiance is.  I would definitely recommend them if you are in the neighborhood. There is a Starbucks a couple of blocks away, but I like giving my money to the smaller businesses.
author: Amber S.

description:
I am not a coffee fanatic, but I love a good, smooth cup made by good peops. Here are other things I love about this coffee stop:

- coffee is is delicious and smooth
- best foam on top ever
- full rainbow of sweetener options are offered
- kind and sweet people work there
- free wireless
- always a parking space within 20 feet of the front door 

:-)
author: Ponytail W.

description:
What a nice staff, I was on my way to work and I had to use the bathroom. I went inside and the employee was very nice to me and gave me access even though I wasnt a customer.
 I'm sure I'll be back for a cup of coffee
author: Erik alexander G.

description:
Well after walking by the wonderful smells of Arizmendi Bakery, my senses were a bit too overwhelmed to try any of their coffee. I ordered a tall glass of whole milk, which wasn't as cold as I would have liked, and my friend a mostly all foam soy latte. 

Meh. It had some cute decor, with an old roaster in the place and tables filled with coffee beans. Nice staff. Can't say I'll be back, as I really don't drink coffee anyway, but I'm all about Fair Trade/Organic Coffee houses and wouldn't not recommend this place to someone.
author: Alita M.

description:
The crew at the Beanery is absolutely the best. Always friendly and nice, which is great first thing in the morning before I've had my coffee. The coffee options are pretty good, although somewhat limited.
That being said, it's a great small corner coffee shop.
author: Patrick K.

description: Yummy latte with a star on top + cool, down-to-earth baristas = Win.
author: Eric F.

description:
Great beans, great espresso drinks.  This place lives up to the high coffee standards of SF.
This is the only place I've seen that carries Ethiopian Harrar beans (most Ethiopian beans are from Yirgacheffe/Sidamo).  Harrar is the best bean in the world.  I'll make the trip to the inner sunset for their beans any day!
author: Dave B.

description: Normally this is one of my favorite places, warm atmosphere and good service. Was shocked to be treated rudely today by both employees, who were much more interested in continuing other conversations than in taking care of me.  Won't be back when these two are around.
author: Kathleen B.

description:
If you're looking to get coffee, tea or me (scratch out the last one!), pastries, juices and other coffee shop fare that are no-nonsense and sans frills, in a setting that is casual, neighborhoody, friendly, quiet, laid back, clean and always smelling of the aroma of freshly ground coffee... then head to The Beanery!

They have a decent selection of coffee and teas and also freshly ground coffee which is a treat. My default is the half decaf and whenever I'm here, I end up running into my neighbors and chatting folks up which really gives this place a community feel. Great staff, great seating outside and a general overall good vibe whenever I am here. (If you see me some time, say hi... I don't bite unless I get "tude"). There is its sister cafe on 9th and Irving as well but hell! this place is a block from my house so I drag my lazy ass here!

Of course, if thou art looking to order a Grande Double Ristretto Venti Nonfat Organic Chocolate Brownie Frappuccino Extra Hot with Foam and Whipped Cream Upside Down Double Blended? You won't get that here... but you'll get it at the Starbucks a couple of blocks down....

... I am silently judging you now...
author: Amit S.

description:
One of the things I miss about Berkeley is the Beanery over on College Ave.  When I first moved here, I was thrilled to find not one, but two, Beanerys within walking distance of my new place.  They seem to run things a little differently on this side of the bay, but still maintain the same commitment to downright delicious coffee and friendly service.

The place is warm and charming, with an unfeigned feel to it that is so difficult to find these days.  It's a good place to lounge and read a book, strike up a conversation with the locals, or just drink in the calm ambiance.

Their French Roast is above par, proffered with a hint of smoky that is well-executed.  To me, though, there's a lot you can tell about a coffee shop by their americanos.  Whether ordering a single or double, I always request extra room.   And at most other coffee shops, they almost always add way too much water, and when I grimace, they just thoughtlessly pour some off, like it's the same thing.  Let me tell you, it's so NOT the same thing.  At the Beanery, they underestimate the amount of the water, and then consistently check with me to see if the volume is to my liking.  These are people who love and understand coffee, my friend.

And, O, that first sip--just heavenly.  Full, balanced, chocolatey, and with just enough kick to get you through your day.
author: Anna L.

description:
So we were having food coma after lots of dim sum and sleepwalking our way through Irving when the aroma comes through our noses like an alarm clock and I could almost taste it just from smelling the roasting from outside. I literally walked backwards as I passed by the cafe.

The cappuccino was great! They have a good and common selection of beans and I like the beans glass top tables. A quiet and small spot for some good caffeine. They also have a good variety of pastries and biscotti. Nice, nice.
author: T L.

description: This was a nice establishment. The guy who made my coffee, sang good and the coffee bean tables......muy goodio
author: freaky r.

description:
Give this place a break guys.

This is a good, casual, neighborhood coffee place where you see a lot of familiar faces. All of the workers here are great people - Joey, Matt, Heather, Rachel (I'm sorry if I misspelled your name...), and etc. The coffee is superb, not like that Starbucks crap, and you end up making friends here. Places like this need to be supported during a crappy economical time when we have soul-less giants like Peet's and such.
author: Courtney S.

description: Favorite coffee shop in the neighbs because the people that work their are shiny but mostly because their coffee is great.
author: Y S.

description: These guys make an amazing white mocha- In my 2 years living in the inner sunset I was able to actively avoid stsarbucks b/c of this coffee shop. I don't know how they make the coffee taste so good, but I'm really glad they're here.
author: Komal B.

description: Had a cup of the french roast which was good. I plan to post an expanded review of this place once I go back and try other things, the people that work there are super nice too.
author: Ely L.

description:
Had a horrible stitch running down 7th on a nine miler I was doing and had to stop to get a drink - I wanted a Vitamin Water, which was 25 cents more than I had. The proprietor very kindly waived the difference with no fuss.

Didn't try the coffee or the pastries, but next time I'm on Irving, I'm going to be sure to get my coffee from there.
author: Will W.

description:
This is a lovely little coffee spot in the inner sunset. The morning staff recognizes me and gets my double nonfat latte going as soon as I go in -- so even if there's a person or 2 ahead of me in line, I get my caffeine fast!. My lattes often come with little hearts or pawprint designs in the foam. Hey, it's a little thing, but it's a nice way to start the day. 

They have a variety of self-serve drip coffees which have always been fresh and tasty when I've gotten them. 

One star off only because the place is  tiny and you can never rely on getting a seat here (although there seem to be a few regulars who do). But the size of the place is not really their fault, and for take-out coffee purposes this place is just fine.
author: Jen C.

description:
STOP WHISTLING!  
For the love of god (whomever your god may be) stop it!  This place too tiny for that shit.  You are not even close to following the tune of what would otherwise be some lovely old-timey jazz playing over the speakers.  And no, pausing only long enough to hock up a loogie or grind espresso beans does not count.   You are scaring the children (and me), what with being the pseudo-crazy-wearin'-your-sunglasses-indoors, Mitch-Hedburg-wannabe-type of character that you've decided to be.  
Lovely chai you make, however.  Delish.

P.S.  I'm using Fireside Bar's  wi-fi connection from across the street.  Seriously?
author: Marlys B.

description: Entertaining barista. Entertaining mustache. Great macchiato.
author: Kevin S.

description: Just a smaller offshoot of their main store on 9th. It's quieter, but the pastry selection is smaller. Still phenomenal coffee, and i come here for beans if i'm over there instead of on 9th.
author: Phuong M.

description:
What I order: Coffee and Americano's.

Every time I order from them, I am shocked at how good it is...not sure why I still keep getting that feeling but I guess it's because no one has such consistency these days.  I've recently started getting ground coffee here as I bought a french press.  First, their prices are very reasonable when compared to the Ritual's or Blue Bottle's.  I love it.  It's local and unique!
author: Sir Paul L.

description: Average. There is wifi and outlets, which is a plus, but the selection of foods is small (just some pastries, no fruit, yogurt, or more hearty breakfast options). I had a cappuccino which was good.
author: Juliana S.

description:
A nice little coffee shop.  I got to the chiropractor's neighborhood an hour early this evening, and rather than visit another Starbucks I decided to patronize a really local business.  Coffee before chiropractic again, I'm such a bad boy.  But I love it!   

The back of the store was crammed with shelving and the steam machine, giving the place a country store feeling.  Cramming all the gear in the back opened up space in the front, though, for four tables inside and three tables outside.  Space enough for the inevitable resident Mac user, and for the rest of us.  The three tables outside were perfect for smoking, sniffing acetone from the nail shop next door, or people watching.  It was a little chilly, but some interesting people happened by, and I was pleased to watch Venus appear in the twilight to the west.  

The coffee was all right.  I ordered a double nonfat latte, and was rewarded with a robust flavor that reminded me of Peets.  They had an assortment of pastries, very similar to the chain coffee shops, as well.  OK, if the coffee was mainly warm milk, I guess I wasn't such a bad boy after all.
author: David D.

description:
This is nothing like the other one.  My first review was mistaken.  

This is not the awesome one off 9th.  The staff here seems much more mellow and, at times, dismissive and non responsive.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
It's a tiny little scrap of a coffee shop, kind of hidden in a nook and overpowered by a nail salon. Yes, it's small and not going to blow your mind with all kinds of brewed to order wifi coffee shop 2.0ness, but overall, I think it's a great little place. It's like the prototypical coffee shop (dark wood paneling, freshly-roasted and ground beans, flyers for dance classes at local community centers), but on a cute little scale. And they have tables outside which gives it a little more capacity, and presumably so people can sit outside with dogs and drink coffee and read the paper and eat scones all day and generally look neighborhood-y. (Who are those people? What do they do for income? How can I get that job?)

Huge selection of tea, and pretty good coffee in four different blend options. You can also buy beans and grounds, which is handy if you like the brew at home thing.
author: Megan W.

description:
Always arriving early for work, i needed to find a spot where i could kill time in the morning... and being right down the block this place showed me some love. Wouldn't you know it? My favorite coffee place in Alameda suddenly became my favorite coffee place in SF too...! (again, for a guy who doesn't drink coffee)

Like in my review for the Alameda Beanery, this place gives you that welcome feeling without that 'elite coffee house' person feeling... I'm just a normal guy who wants to enjoy a bagel and water, and this place makes me feel good.

It's small, also, which is probably a plus since i don't like a lot of traffic while i read my newspaper. They have outside seating for people watching, too. The guy who runs this place in the morning is extremely friendly and always acts like he remembers you.

Overall i think this is a great little spot in the lower sunset with good bagels and extra friendly service!
author: Greg G.

description:
No matter how much evidence arises saying that there are benefits to drinking coffee I must say that I beg to differ. However, I sometimes sneak a sip from a friend and now - due to my appreciation for coffee from the beanery - I sneak whole cups. Damn coffee is addicting. I get it with soy and its so deliciously sweet and smooth. Sometimes if you get a singing tall man making your drinks he will not only serenade you but will put a pretty pic in your drink. Their bagels toasted with cream cheese are great (and I am picky). 

!
author: Sari G.

description:
This place is literally a stonesthrow away from my digs, thereby allowing me to dash over in my PJs, get my java and be back watching cartoons in less than 3 minutes.

the good: great coffee aka "the elixir of life"
the bad: the so-so pastry selection
the ugly: me in the morning before my first sip
author: Emily L.

description:
" Love, love, love, love, love, love, love, love, love.
There's nothing you can do that can't be done..
Nothing you can sing that can't be sung..
Nothing you can say but you can learn how to play the game
It's easy...!
There's nothing you can make that can't be made..
No one you can save that can't be saved..
Nothing you can do but you can learn how to be in time
It's easy....! "

All you need is: THE BEANERY!
All you need is: THE BEANERY!

And a "double non-fat mocha, no whip"
$3.10

- I go there almost every morning (If the N-Judah threatens to leave my ass whimpering on 7th & Judah, I'll skip the caffeine)
- I love the guys & gals who work there - they're funny, they're warm, they recognise me and feed me coffee.

The Beatles and I? - We think alike.
author: Anjali V.

description:
I was going to give this place two stars, but I think I'm really wanting 2.5 stars, so it seems I'll round up.

I met a friend here, who studies at this place all day long (for that, I rounded up--kudos to the beanery for allowing long study sessions) and I was sad to see how stiff and hard and uncomfortable the seating was.

I could forgive this, if the coffee were any good.

Let me say I have an enormously high standard for coffee.  Yes, I know everyone says this...but both my parents are European, I grew up drinking espresso made the "right way" and american coffee needs only to not taste like bile or burnt to a crisp beans that will churn in my stomach for hours.

I've long given up finding a decent espresso made by non-European hands with a push button machine (hence, my thousasnd dollar Pavoni at home) but my "regular coffee" shouldn't need to be doused in 1 part milk and 6 tablespoons of sugar to mask the bitter.

I'd go back, because they were nice, but I'll stick to tea, and not sit down...in and out.  That's what this place would be for me.

If you don't mind the hard-ass seats, and a cup full of bitter, this may be the place for you.
author: Lisa B.

description: Understated, but excellent coffee they roast themselves.  Waaaayyy beter than other chain based coffees.  Pastries are not made in house, but are excellent.
author: p w.

description:
Great little neighborhood coffee shop.  Good lattes and good selection of pastries and other goodies (bagels, a few flavored creme cheeses).  I don't think I really need to say this, but it's WAY better than the Starbuck$ down the street and closer to my house.

The guy who works the afternoons is my favorite.  He always draws a little star in my latte with the foam.  He once said "Man, I had this crazy dream last night  that I came to work with no pants on.  And then I realized I wasn't actually asleep."  You can't beat that!
author: James M.

description:
Feeling the effects of food coma after lunch one afternoon, I decided to check out this little spot across the street.

I walked in groggy, the coma was setting in and I just wasn't functioning properly.  I looked over the cashier for the coffee menu, and none was to be found.  Slipping slowly into food induced oblivion, I asked the ultra hippie dude behind the counter "do you serve iced coffee?"

It was as if I had somehow slapped Sir Hippie of the Coffee Beanery with my question...he gave me a "you-are-a-total-dumbass" answer and told me to look to my right because all the drinks they serve are up there and they even have iced choices (I could feel the silent "duh" from across the counter).

How could I know?!  I was deep, deep in the throws of food coma!  How could this seemingly calm and gentle hippie creature turn so sour and cold on me?  I thought all hippies were kind and gentle and understanding of those who were out of it?!  Alas, this was not one of those hippies =(

I humbly ordered my iced coffee and left feeling dejected and lame.  The coffee was so good that I quickly forgot the sting of humiliation at the hands of Sir Hippie of the Coffee Beanery.  

A 4 star establishment with -1 star for the extra helping of hippie sass.
author: Christy L.

description: What a cute place! It's super cozy and friendly and warm inside. The baristas are very friendly and the coffee is excellent. I ordered a Caramel Latte and it was incredibly smooth and rich. Also love that the wi-fi is free.
author: Shreya O.

description:
This is my place. I mean, I don't own it, nor would I want to (because then I'd have to do all the work) but they KNOW coffee, man. They KNOW it. 

The basics: drip coffee- always fresh, always hot, always gooooood. None of that drippy brown water shit. It's REAL coffee- not chewy, mind you, just solid and does you right. I believe they have mostly Central American and Indonesian beans- may serve African from time to time, but regardless, the roast is just right - no burned over-achieving crap like Starbucks (who DID bring coffee to the masses, but their roasting is awful). Beanery roast is even and rich- and no, I don't know if those words generally work for coffee, but they do for me.

Lattes- I stay away from milk because, well, it gives me scary tummy aches, but that's the thing- they make a soy latte here that is not overwhelmed by the espresso- they know the right combo of soy milk to espresso. And their other drinks are made well, too- I was a "barista" at some Southeastern coffee store mall chain, but we were so bored we took the time to make a good cappuccino, and the Beanery folks are REAL baristas, but don't overdo it. They don't need to prove their coffee-ness- they just do it (unlike some Seattle shops that seem to think that taking longer means it will be better- not so).

You can also buy beans or ground coffee by the half pound and pound, and the prices are really great- around $8 for a pound of a medium roasted something. Bring your bag back and get a dime off the next pound- not huge, but a nice touch that does keep me coming back (among other reasons).

The baristas are not overly chatty but friendly enough. Forrest, as someone else mentioned, makes a nice little heart design in the top of lattes and cappuccinos, and someone else makes a little paw print (avec milk, not paws). I prefer the paws, but Forrest has mad skeelz, regardless.

This place is my favorite coffee place in the city, hands down. And the 7th Avenue (nee, Judah) is one tiny step above the 9th Avenue sister, due to it's location- it's out of the hubbub around the 9th/Judah intersection and is a little bit more chill.
author: Bethany P.

description:
Awkward seems like a strange adjective for a coffee shop, but that's all that comes to mind. 

The counter set up was weird, with the menu facing one way and the counters making an L-shape.. where to order? Ahh, confusion abounds before I even decide if I want coffee or tea.

Then comes trying to find a seat... Being that there are like two chairs inside, that was kind of a problem, so I went outside, but alas it was cold. Came back inside, sat in a chair with no table. That was weird. Finally someone got up from their table and I stole their spot. Moving spots three times in one visit -- not a good sign.

Finally, seated comfortably with a drink and a table, and I couldn't concentrate on the conversation I was having because the barista kept whistling. I know, right? And at any other time I would have found that totally endearing, but I was just so frazzled by this point, I couldn't handle it.

Two stars for the delish coffee and the friendly service -- and barista, if you read this, do keep whistling. It was rad, I just wasn't in the right mindset.
author: Laura P.

description:
I'm addicted to coffee.  If I don't have a cup of joe a day, I enter complete psycho bitch mode and lose all sense of focus.  My limbs quiver uncontrollably.  It's a $2 per day drug that I must have.

All this coffee drinking makes me somewhat of an expert when it comes to picking out good coffee drinks.  

With super-coffee shops like Starbucks and Pete's, where baristas crank out drinks a mile a minute, it's like no one knows how to make good espresso drinks.  The milk foam usually looks like bubble bath on top of your drink.  I've heard of the term "wash your mouth out with soap", but I never expected to think about it every time I get my morning beverage.  Foam is my favorite part.  Get that right and I'm sold!

The little roaster that could gets it right.  There is a woman at the espresso bar that makes a mean milk foam.  Whatever the secret is, she knows it and makes the bubbles fine and creamy looking--just how you would find it in Europe.  Save yourself the trouble of the long line at Starbucks and walk around the corner to this gem (snuggled right next to Arizmendi and the Mucky Duck Saloon, just in front of the 44 bus stop).

Delish!
author: Steph M.

description:
I've been here twice now, and this place serves up the best iced mocha I've had so far. Their prices are great and their snacks look really good (although I haven't had a chance to try any yet).

As others have mentioned the place itself is a bit small, but it's close enough to the park so you can get your caffeinated beverage of choice to go and cruise there to hang out...I guess you can also go sit at one of the tables in front of Starbucks, but you didn't hear that from me, m'kay?
author: Art D.

description: Ever single person that works here is always so nice. This is my favorite coffee place.
author: Denise S.

description:
I usually grab coffee from this place when I need it to fuel me through a 7am hourlong commute to Mountain View from SF.  It's lovely and quiet at 6am, with crisp Bach usually playing in the early darkness.  Servers are usually not so harried and generally more pleasant at this early hour -- arrive after 7am, when the lines are beginning to form... and the goodwill seems to diminish somewhat.

For standard plain coffee - grab a cup and fill up from the thermoses at the counter nearest to the door.  Place your latte, cappucino, espresso orders with the barrista in the back.

There's a water bowl for puppies out front, and on occasion, your well-behaved tethered furry friend will receive a cookie from the servers.
author: Claudine C.

description:
This is my "other" favorite cafe (Beanery) but at a different location (like literally two blocks from the one on 9th Avenue). Same lovely cafe - good lattes - good bagels - minus the antique roaster at this location.

As to how I'd decide which one to go to...is highly dependent upon the time of the day. I'd go to the one on 9th Avenue in the morning when the sun rises in the east till about 1pm or so, then I would prefer to go to the one on Irving/7th Ave. when the sun starting to slowly set in the west. 

I hope you'd find this handy dandy sunrise/sunset time-telling tip helpful especially for people like me who prefer to sit outside and enjoy the rare sunshine that the sunset district brings. Despite the lack of sunny days compared to the Mission District, I still love this neighborhood and especially this cafe!
author: Jen L.

description:
Stopped by because I was looking for a new place to study. Great when it's a sunny day 'cause then you can grab one of the tables outside, soak in the sun (with your sunblock on, of course) and do your thing as you casually people-watch every  now and then.

Coffee tastes like coffee. No added frills here.
author: Janel Y.

description:
Nice cozy neighborhood cafe on the corner of a busy intersection. It's a great place to sit and read, or people-watch when it's nice outside. The barista, I think his name is Forrest, is friendly and makes a lovely mocha. One time he didn't have any more whipped cream (nooo), but he made a heart out of the foam on top, which was really sweet.

Also, the lemon bars here are delicious. If that's too sweet for your sweet tooth, go for a lemon poppyseed cookie.
author: Liz L.

description:
So small.  Shares an awning with the salon next door.  Small tables.  No wi-fi (a trend in coffee houses in the Inner Sunset- WTF?)  Nice for sipping and people-watching on the less-busy corner of 7th/Irving, but not a place I'd go to study or get things done.  (Haven't you heard?  Coffee shops are the office of the 21st century.)
The coffee is self-serve, hot, and very good.  I have yet to try any espresso-containing beverages or pastries (I rolled with a bagel from down the street).
author: Eric S.

description: Bad coffee, reasonably nice staff, unattractive structure.
author: Travis L.

description: Coffee: very good and consistent. Staff: It really depends on when you go there. We love Forest,& Gwen but some morning staff a bit controlling and drama, drama, drama. Not what we need before coffee.
author: Alison B.

description: Wow, I just happened to be in the inner sunset and had a kick-ass cappuccino here. Nice barista too.
author: Michael H.

description: This is where E. was all along, looking up occasionally to see where I might be, not knowing I was waiting under similar circumstances down the street at Beanery, wondering the same thing. I had the French Roast here ($1.75 lg.) and for some reason, it didn't taste as good as the one I had at the Beanery. In the future, I want to choose a place to meet E. which has a unique name not shared by any other place in the City. Quiet little spot, not too crowded..nice place to chat or do homework as the woman at the next table was doing.
author: michael s.

description: very excellent coffee and espresso, great customers and a friendly place to hang out.  Although it's often freezing cold and they should give their customer blankets, turn off the fans whens its 50 degrees or shot the door.
author: Rob W.

description: Forrest Huggins is the best damn Barista in the inner Sunset! Tell him to do an Elvis impression when you go in there.
author: Liz N.

description:
The canopy outside was misleading (since apparently they shared it with the nail salon next door). It said something like Coffee, Hair, Nails, Vag Wax (OK maybe not the last one). 

It smelled like pee when I walked into this place. Not that appealing. I got a cappuccino to go for my walk in the park. Coffee was OK. Its a small place, and I imagine it would be a nice place to go for a coffee after a walk in the park or a date.

Its an OK choice for the area.
author: Rocky K.

description: small tables. cramped seating space.  can't spread out and study (to be fair this i my main criteria for a coffee shop and it might not be yours) Coffee is fine.  Staff are nice.  Since it's such a small space and it's in the inner sunset, it's ice cold to sit in there when they leave the door open.  better order your drink extra hot!
author: Meg M.

description:
The good:  Organic Fair trade coffee, friendly service, clean bathroom, good selection of coffee and pastries.  

The Bad:  Too crampt: tables are inches apart and it can be difficiult to get a table at all.

This is where I hang out most mornings as long as I can get a seat.  Thereis a friendly neighborly feeling and the owner is nice.  I used to go to another cafe in the lower Haight (for 10 years )and they NEVER remembered my usual order.  Here, they start making my drink as soon as they see me walk through the door.  The place is very celean.  In fact its amost a minus as the Barristas are constantly sweeping the floor.

If  they got rid of that  "cute" Roaster which takes up half the freakin room, the place might be a little more roomy and feel a little more relaxed.

Like, Meg, I have seen many people recieve the same courtesy regarding paying next time.  I've also seen them give food to homeless people.   The owner is a good guy.
NOTE: There are two Beaneries owned by the same guy about 2 blocks apart.  This review is for the larger one on 9th and Irving.  The other one is on 7th and Irving and is much smaller.
author: W M.

description:
The Owner is bright friendly and fun!

The Mocha Java Coffee is delicious and strong as can be.

There's a cup discount if you bring your own, that makes your coffee just 1.40

And there's god fast internet from the Fireside bar across the street.

The pastries are yummy.

It's got to be one of the best Coffee shops I've tried in San Francisco, with the Lazy Dog being another very good one!
author: Brendan M.

description: The BEST organic French beans EVER.  I take this wherever I go when I have to leave San Francisco, even if I'm going to Seattle.  Perhaps the only place I wouldn't take these magical beans is to Italy, where I used to live; italianissima, sono!
author: Lucia M.

description: Surprised to see such low ratings for this place.  I've ducked in here a few times to grab some morning joe and I've always had a pleasant experience and left with a nice beverage (either coffee or espresso) in hand.
author: Melissa Y.

description: Pretty good coffee, but it just felt like they didn't really give a sh*t about anything other than that. Kind of a mess and the trash hadn't been emptied for a while. Not a big deal, but not anywhere I would stop with someone else again.
author: Jason R.

description: This review is based on only one visit.  I recently bought their fair trade, organic coffee beans--the house blend--and found that the beans were incredibly stale and entirely devoid of flavor.  It's true that the owner and the barista were friendly.  But I'm afraid that's not enough to make up for bad beans.
author: Chad W.

description: The mustached barista handed us our americanos and sat down, making a non sequitor joke about paternal sexual abuse. He removed his baseball cap revealing a rat's nest of a hairdo. Muttering the words "rat's nest" he fingered the rat's nest thoroughly and affectionately. Nervously holding our americanos, we looked at  each other before taking a potentially fatal sip and left.
author: Jeremy L.

description: Arizmendi plus The Beanery. Could life get any better? Sometimes I wanna roll out of bed, get a good coffee, something to dip into my coffee, and relax. After my stroll through Arizmendi The Beanery is the perfect place to sit and enjoy my "goodies". Plus I love going to a place that actually sells their coffee and tea by the pound.
author: rachel c.

description: I love the soy chai latte here.  Great, friendly service and quick too!  I have never waited for more than 2 minutes for my drink.  And you get a discount if you bring your own cup and there is a punch card! Only drawback is that it is cash only.
author: Amireh G.

description: Friendly barista in good spirits serving up a good soy latte with no wait, with plenty of vegan Alternative Bakery Cookies on hand.  Can be a little tight space-wise, and there is no soft seating.  A nice place to hang out.
author: Bob G.

description: I'm giving them 4 stars because when I showed up with no cash and had already ordered hot tea when I find out they only take cash they said don't worry about it, get us next time. What!? am I still in san francisco, they wont do this for you at starbucks thats for sure. So of course I came back and paid the next day plus bought some more caffeinated beverages. Their pastry selection wasn't  very diverse or enticing but for service alone I will be returning. Plus their is always people there looking happy, I want to be one of those people!
author: Meg L.

description: One star better than the Starbuckaruse, but $1.85 for a so-so espresso. The cashier seemed to be a mute balding 'roid, that did not know how to smile or express a thank you for your business. Must have been a rejected 'roid from an old EmpireStrikes casting.
author: miriam b.

description: I had the worse latte here today. It was very bitter and smelled like burnt plastic. If I didn't need the caffeine I would have thrown it out! I've had their drip coffee on another occasion and it was decent. The two stars are for the friendly people behind the register.
author: Stacy F.

description: Very good.  their french organic coffee is my favorite.  It is a bit small, so sometimes it's frustrating if you want to sit and read, but the coffee is excellent.  Their muffins are really good to, especially the zuchinni pecan.  The staff are super sweet and friendly and I love chatting with them every morning. only real downside is they don't have wireless.
author: Sky B.

description: Are you tired of onerous government regulations like, say, the health code? If so, this is the coffee shop for you! My husband liked the coffee here on several visits, but never again. The last time I walked in, the coffee-slinger was smoking outside. After taking his sweet time finishing up that cigarette, he wandered back in and started making coffee and grabbing pastries from the case without washing his hands. And although many of these reviews talk about nice employees, this guy certainly wasn't one of them. We still walk by and consistent with that experience, this place is a smoker's paradise; the air outside is so bad that we cross the street when we're with our kids. As there are thousands of smoking hipsters in this city, I have little doubt that this place will do good business for years to come unless, by some happy miracle, they are ever inspected.
author: D E A.

description: Besides the weird one-eyed Chinese man who gawked at me for about 5 minutes until I told him to "shoo" the Beanery is a pretty mellow cafe. You must get one of the chocolate chip cookies they sell at the counter. It's soft and doughy and LOADED with sugar, but so tasty....
author: Kat F.

description: Great staff and consistent coffee. They actually know how to make a dry cappuccino.
author: Robert M.

description: High quality gourmet, also fair trade certified coffee.  The owner is very friendly and they have a wide variety of coffees, especially if you like the dark and bold varieties.  The mocha java is my fave.  They also have every other espresso drink you can think of.  A small place, but they do have a few tables if you wanna sit.  It's a good place to grab a coffee and run.
author: Chi N.

description: Excellent coffee and espresso.  Fewer seats than the sister location on 9th (@ Irving)
author: Patrick L.

description: Love the strong coffee, just wish there was a little more variety on drip. Ample seating, great atmosphere, friendly staff. I heard about the crazy owner and was grateful I didn't run into him.
author: Teresa Y.

description: Aww. I like this place. It's cute and the staff people are nice. Their coffee is GOOD--I got some kind of roasted drip, and it was awesome. I got a soy latte here once and it was good, too. And they carry my favorite brand of vegan cookie! I'm a fan.
author: Ramon E.

description: This place is just down the street from my house and when the owner is in, the service is incredible.  The zuchinni bran muffin is great and their coffee strong and good.  The employees in the evenings can be kinda flaky and what I wouldn't give for it to have an credit/debit machine...  I really think they lose a lot of business that way.  I'll support local over Starbuck's any day but sometimes I just don't have cash.
author: Lauren L.

description: I just went here for the first time, and when I realized I didn't have any cash, the guy at the counter gave me my coffee and said I could just pay next time - awesome! The coffee is real tasty, too.
author: Andrew H.

description:
the organic french roast is awesome.
not a lot of seating inside, but sitting outside isn't too bad unless it's midmorning and the sun is right in your eyes- also, the tables and chairs are right on top of each other.  expect to hear a lot of whistling from the barista.
author: Maggie D.

description: I had some fun witty banter with the barista here, and th customers also joined in and a fun time was had.  That being said, the coffee was only OK and it was very small.
author: Aaron W.

description: I'm a coffee snob. The double-shot espresso was the best I've had in a long long time. The Sumatra beans I bought worked well for me at home too.
author: Becky H.

description: Not to be confused with Beanery (up the block a little), this place is mediocre.  Beans aren't stale but aren't always really fresh either, and the baristas don't always pull good shots.  I've had one or two with good crema and nice body, but a bunch that were tamped unevenly and ended up bitter and watery.  Their foam is nothing special either, just the usual stiff soapsud stuff.  Service is friendly and the tables out on Irving are fantastic, though.
author: Akshay S.

description: I get coffee or tea here almost every day.  It's right across from the N and serves better coffee than anywhere downtown.  The staff are also extremely friendly, which really matters when they're dealing with people who just woke up and haven't had a cup yet.
author: Chad S.

description:
Yuuuuummmm!
Great location adjacent to N-Judah, and take my order of a mocha with extra chocolate with only minimal chuckles
author: Kristin C.

description:
Possibly the worst chocolate croissant I've ever had.  It was actually gummy.

The coffee was fine, but when they announced "double mocha" I asked, "Is it decaf?", and the barista looked at the cashier for a moment and then the barista said, "Yes."  I wasn't convinced.  They seem to be making coffee so chaotically I wonder if their quality is consistent?  

They don't use real whipping cream, either, which is always a bummer and loses points with real food snobs.
author: Marta L.

description:
An old Stiff Records slogan comes to mind: Fuck art, let's dance. 

Several fresh varieties of  whole beans sold,  some of which are roasted a block away at "the other beanery."  
Brewed coffee choices can include Sumatran or Colombian Supremo, in addition to one or two other standards such as Mocha Java, and a Roaster's blend. 
Espresso drinks are well crafted, and served quickly, without  fanfare (ahem..Blue Bottle, take note here, anyone can learn to be a Barista).
Lattes and cappuccinos! Foam density, milk to coffee ratio, temperature...all usually perfect. Occasional inclusion of  foam art takes nothing away from overall drinkability. 
One thing, though: The cafe mocha is less desirable than other drinks, owing to the overly sweet chocolate syrup used. 
While the coffee offerings warrant 4 1/2 stars, the baked goods have problems.  Croissants are puffy and overly dough-ish,  like wonder bread. Pastries  are run of the mill, and are similar to those sold by Costco. Not tasty, not disgusting, just unremarkable and boring. Who cares really? Arizmendi is nearby and nothing can touch that shit. Nothing. 

Bullshit index is low. . 
Pretense is remarkably absent. The furniture, decor, artwork and basic layout could be described as somewhat sterile, by those who prefer a more  contrived experience. This place is about the coffee and the people (staff and patrons alike) in that order. 
Weirdos, healers, musicians, carpenters, pot-heads, and smart alecs mingle and banter,  morning until evening, with bio-capitalists, researchers, execs, mommas, daddies, nannas and pappas
 And then there is Forrest, who often provides something completely different. Don't plan on operating heavy machines after encountering him. He is dope you cannot smoke. 
In short, the 602 Irving Beanery kick ass because the prime directives are met: 
great coffee; no agenda. .
author: Him Big B.

description: Decently priced coffee - the location is convenient - just grab it and go!
author: Dawn N.

description:
I sometimes get a cup of this after the gym.   I think I bought a bag of this coffee 2 years ago and really liked it then too.

It is definitely a decent cup of coffee, and probably the best roast in the neighborhood.  I just get the regular brew.  If they have a single cup drip brew or press pot maybe I will give up the last star but I do not know if I can order that.  

Even so, It's just  good. Does not induce a need to have this particular type of coffee.
author: Brandon W.

description: I love the beanery!!! They make great great coffees with great prices and they are fast. I practically live there.
author: Kismet S.

description: besides always having a good experience here, i recently went in one morning needing to use the bathroom badly so i bought a cup of coffee just to get to the point and relieve myself. after like ten minutes the guy working there went next door and arranged for me to be able to use the bathroom there because his bathroom was occupied so long. big shout out to the nice lady next door at the nail salon too.
author: Kevin L.

description: My favorite coffee place in California. Every time I bring someone there they talk about it afterwards as the best, smoothest coffee they have ever had. Please don't go to Starbucks just go to The Beanery.
author: Nikki T.

description: I'm not sure if the barista was having a bad day, but he was certainly rude. We found him smoking outside and when we asked for coffee in a regular cup (not a disposable cup), he said that disposable was all they had. The fact that he didnt bother to wash his hands (after smoking) before making our latte was also a bit disconcerting. anyways.. like I said, he might have had a bad day. For all its flaws, the starbucks down the road certainly seems friendlier now.
author: Getafix O.

description: i think i have a crush on the quirky male barista with the long hair. hes hot...in a weird way. and great coffee!
author: Auvignal L.

description: this place is great! Not only was it the best vanilla latte i have ever had, I got it for free! I didn't have any cash on me and they don't take credit cards. As I walked out the owner insisted he make it for free. The people that work here are extremely nice, the place is warm and homey, and the coffee is the best cup I've had around this neighborhood so far. Definitely will return to the beanery for a pick me up when work gets me down.
author: Yasmine A.
